Boeing wins a $4.2 billion contract from NASA to send astronauts to  and from  the International Space Station.
SpaceX receives a $2.6 billion contract as well with the same goals.
The intention was to end reliance on Russia for space travel by 2017, as astronauts have flown to the ISS on Russian spacecraft since 2011.
NASA expresses concerns about Starliner's parachute system, as reported by the U.S. Government Accountability Office, predicting certification delays to 2020.
Boeing identifies an 'anomaly' during a test of Starliner's launch abort system, leading to a propellant leak.
This system is critical for pulling the spacecraft away from the rocket during emergencies.
Starliner fails its flight test to reach the ISS as it does not enter the correct orbit, failing to dock at the ISS.
NASA attributes this to issues with the spacecraft's mission elapse timing system.
Boeing and NASA cancel Starliner's mission due to valve issues in the propulsion system.
Starliner is sent back to the factory for deeper-level troubleshooting.
Starliner safely returns from its second orbital flight test, but the docking at the ISS was described as 'nail biting'.
Issues included problems with software, sensors, docking components, and thrusters.
Engineers found 'six or seven' possible causes.
American astronaut Frank Rubio travels to the ISS with two Russian cosmonauts for a six-month mission aboard the Russian spacecraft Soyuz MS-22.
The Soyuz spacecraft is damaged, possibly by space junk, causing a coolant leak and preventing Frank Rubio from returning to earth.
Astronaut Frank Rubio returns to earth on a different Soyuz model, Soyuz MS-23, after setting a new record for the most consecutive days in space by an American, at 371 days.
Williams and Wilmore launch into space from Cape Canaveral, Florida, in Starliner for what was supposed to be a week-long mission.
Their capsule experienced a helium leak in its propulsion system before departure and had four more leaks during flight.
Starliner docks at the ISS after about 26 hours.
Issues with helium leaks and the reaction control thrusters persist, with as many as five thrusters going offline during the voyage.
NASA and Boeing announce the postponement of Starliner's return to finalize departure planning and operations.
They emphasize the opportunity to perform more tests providing invaluable data.

NASA postpones Starliner's return again to June 26 to further investigate the thruster malfunctions and helium leaks, with the aim of learning as much as possible while the service module is in orbit.
Boeing reports losing $125 million on the Starliner program in its quarterly earnings report, bringing the total losses since 2016 to $1.6 billion.
Boeing extends the astronauts' mission until February, deciding to bring them back on a SpaceX aircraft due to safety concerns.
Wilmore detects a strange 'pulsing' noise from a speaker in Starliner, attributed by NASA to an audio configuration issue between the space station and Starliner.
Starliner returns to earth unmanned, landing at White Sands Space Harbor in New Mexico.
Williams and Wilmore remain at the ISS, citing safety concerns over the thruster problems, though Stich mentions the landing would have likely been safe with the crew on board.
